---
slug: /235
title: "This Week In React #235: React Router, createStore, SuspenseList, Transition Indicator, Compiler, RenderHooks, Waku, React-Scan | Expo, Lava, Fortnite, Skia, AI, Lynx | TC39, using, Zod, Node, Deno"
authors: [slorber]
date: 05-21-2025
---
Hi everyone!

This week, we're delighted to finally have a preview of React Server Components support in React Router. I've also found some very interesting PRs on the React repo, and give you a glimpse of what could be coming soon!

segments.source_content: ## âš›ï¸ React {#react}
[![React Router RSC Preview](/emails/issues/235/rr.jpg)](https://remix.run/blog/rsc-preview)
**[React Router RSC Preview](https://remix.run/blog/rsc-preview)**

The React Router team unveiled a preview of React Server Components support using the Parcel bundler. Stable support is blocked until Vite officially supports RSCs, but the good news is that React Router is becoming more framework-agnostic, and they expect to support other bundlers in the future with minimal effort.

translations.fr: L'Ã©quipe React Router a dÃ©voilÃ© un aperÃ§u de la prise en charge des React Server Components avec le bundler Parcel. Le support stable est bloquÃ© jusqu'Ã  ce que Vite prenne officiellement en charge les RSC, mais React Router devient plus agnostique aux frameworks et prÃ©voit de supporter d'autres bundlers avec un effort minimal.
translations.en: L'Ã©quipe React Router a dÃ©voilÃ© un aperÃ§u du support des React Server Components utilisant le bundler Parcel. Le support stable est bloquÃ© jusqu'Ã  ce que Vite prenne officiellement en charge les RSC, mais la bonne nouvelle est que React Router devient plus agnostique vis-Ã -vis des frameworks, et ils prÃ©voient de supporter d'autres bundlers Ã  l'avenir avec un effort minimal.

segments.source_content: The feature is designed to be both incrementally adoptable by returning JSX in loaders/actions, but also to feel good on new greenfield projects looking to go all-in with Server Component Routes, `â€™use clientâ€™` and `â€™use serverâ€™` directives. They also explain how to solve the N+1 query problem in RSCs, inspired by GraphQL/DataLoader.

translations.en: La fonctionnalitÃ© est conÃ§ue pour Ãªtre adoptÃ©e de maniÃ¨re incrÃ©mentielle en renvoyant du JSX dans les loaders/actions, mais aussi pour Ãªtre agrÃ©able sur les nouveaux projets greenfield souhaitant aller Ã  fond avec les Server Component Routes, les directives `â€™use clientâ€™` et `â€™use serverâ€™`. Ils expliquent Ã©galement comment rÃ©soudre le problÃ¨me de requÃªte N+1 dans les RSC, inspirÃ© par GraphQL/DataLoader.

fr.translation: La fonctionnalitÃ© est conÃ§ue pour une adoption progressive via le retour de JSX dans les loaders/actions, mais aussi pour les nouveaux projets souhaitant utiliser intensivement les Server Component Routes et les directives `'use client'`/`'use server'`. Ils expliquent Ã©galement comment rÃ©soudre le problÃ¨me des requÃªtes N+1 dans les RSC, inspirÃ© par GraphQL/DataLoader.
fr.reason: Content of a non-translatable 'inlineCode' element was changed. Source: '`â€™use clientâ€™`', Translation: '`'use client'`'.

segments.source_content: [![Render Hooks](/emails/issues/235/renderhook.jpg)](https://github.com/brandonmcconnell/render-hooks)
**[Render Hooks](https://github.com/brandonmcconnell/render-hooks) and [With React](https://github.com/jacobparis/with-react)**

Looks like the Render Props pattern is making a comeback, with 2 new projects proposing to expose React core hooks in a render callback. This is a convenient trick in some situations, allowing you to "inline" a component while still respecting the rules of hooks, but it does not really solve any problem that canâ€™t be solved by extracting a custom component. An interesting pattern to use sparingly.

translations.fr: Le pattern Render Props semble faire son retour, avec 2 nouveaux projets exposant les hooks React de base via un callback de rendu. C'est une astuce pratique dans certains cas pour "inliner" un composant tout en respectant les rÃ¨gles des hooks, mais elle ne rÃ©sout pas de problÃ¨me insoluble par un composant personnalisÃ©. Un pattern intÃ©ressant Ã  utiliser avec parcimonie.
translations.en: Il semble que le pattern Render Props fasse son retour, avec 2 nouveaux projets proposant d'exposer les hooks React de base dans un callback de rendu. C'est une astuce pratique dans certaines situations, vous permettant d'"inliner" un composant tout en respectant les rÃ¨gles des hooks, mais cela ne rÃ©sout pas vraiment de problÃ¨me qui ne pourrait Ãªtre rÃ©solu en extrayant un composant personnalisÃ©. Un pattern intÃ©ressant Ã  utiliser avec parcimonie.

- ğŸ’¸ [Product for Engineers - What engineers get wrong about communication](https://go.posthog.com/twir-may21)
- ğŸ‘€ [React Core PR \- `createStore()` skeleton API](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/33215): Initial scaffolding work to implement the Concurrent Stores feature mentioned in the latest React Labs update. Thereâ€™s no implementation yet, but I still find it interesting to check the signature/types of this upcoming API that should support both ad-hoc state updates and the reducer/actions pattern. What strikes me the most is that you canâ€™t access the store value directly, apart from using the `use(store)` API, and this totally makes sense in a concurrent world. Remember, this is a work in progress, and things may change.
- ğŸ‘€ [React Core PRs \- `<SuspenseList>` being actively worked on](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Afacebook%2Freact+SuspenseList&type=pullrequests&s=created&o=desc): Itâ€™s been a while since we last heard of this upcoming component that we thought would be in React 18\. It allows to coordinate Suspense boundaries and control their â€œreveal orderâ€ (forwards/backwards/together).
- ğŸ‘€ [React Core PR \- Transition indicator \+ `onDefaultTransitionIndicator` API](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/33162): A feature being worked on should allow giving user feedback while React transitions are in progress. The default React-DOM implementation should show a native browser spinner, but itâ€™s possible to opt out or provide a custom feedback.
- ğŸ‘€ [SWC PR \- Initialize `@swc/react-compiler`](https://github.com/swc-project/swc/pull/10475): A new package to integrate the React Compiler for all SWC-based projects is coming. It will still use Babel under the hood ([details](https://github.com/oxc-project/oxc/issues/10048#issuecomment-2837628965)), but itâ€™s possible to optimize by only running it on relevant files (see what [Next.js is doing](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/config/next-config-js/reactCompiler)), potentially using parallelization.
- ğŸ‘€ [Next.js PR \- Initial Segment Explorer devtool](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/78858): The Next.js team started working on a tool to help you visualize parallel and interception route segments.
- ğŸ” [Next.js Race Condition to Cache Poisoning \- CVE-2025-32421](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-qpjv-v59x-3qc4): Low-severity Pages Router vulnerability, already patched.

It positions itself as a direct Vercel competitor, although there are differences (containers vs serverless). Itâ€™s a paid cloud product, but you can also self-host it for free.
- ğŸ“œ [Concurrent Rendering](https://ui.dev/c/react/concurrent-rendering): Free interactive lesson on React transitions from the ui.dev course.
- ğŸ“œ [Correctly infers from initial props](https://rena.to/blog/13): You donâ€™t need to explicitly type your context value and can leverage type inference instead.
- ğŸ“œ [Making Next.js Navigation Fast af](https://upstash.com/blog/fast-nextjs): Using React Router within your Next.js app works, but I doubt itâ€™s a good idea, doesnâ€™t permit you to use RSCs, and is likely to cause trouble if you use different routers on different pages.
- ğŸ“œ [Mastering Focus Management in React with `flushSync`](https://www.epicreact.dev/mastering-focus-management-in-react-with-flush-sync-f5b38): By default, React uses batching and doesnâ€™t flush state updates immediately to the DOM, and you can opt out of this behavior when needed.
- ğŸ“œ [Preserving and Resetting State in React](https://www.epicreact.dev/preserving-and-resetting-state-in-react-l2dxl): Explains why conditionally wrapping a component may make it reset its state.
- ğŸ“œ [Just F\*\*\*ing Use React](https://justfuckingusereact.com/): Entertaining read, also exists in a less profane [Just Use React](https://www.epicreact.dev/just-use-react-dk4e0) variant.

- ğŸ“¦ [Waku 0.23 \- Fine-grained component render modes](https://waku.gg/blog/fine-grained-router-components): Makes it possible to statically pre-render parts of a dynamic page. I find the API a bit confusing, but the idea looks cool and simpler than Next.js Partial Pre-Rendering.
- ğŸ“¦ [React-Scan 0.3.4 \- Scan for React performance issues](https://github.com/aidenybai/react-scan/releases/tag/v0.3.4): A release that takes the opportunity to announce upcoming features and the availability of the [extension on the Chrome store](https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/react-scan/anmmhkomejbdklkhoiloeaehppaffmdf).

segments.source_content: ## ğŸ”€ Other {#other}

- ğŸ‘€ [TC39 \- Agenda for the 108th meeting](https://github.com/tc39/agendas/blob/main/2025/05.md): Next week, another set of interesting proposals for JS could progress, some of them could become part of the standard: `using` keyword, `Error.isError()`.
- ğŸ“œ [JavaScript's New Superpower: Explicit Resource Management](https://v8.dev/features/explicit-resource-management): Describes the `using` keyword mentioned above, already available in Chrome, and more importantly, in Node 24\.
- ğŸ“œ [The Future of MCP is GraphQL](https://www.apollographql.com/blog/the-future-of-mcp-is-graphql): Apollo announcing their MCP server, explaining the alignment between GraphQL and AI needs.
- ğŸ“œ [I think the ergonomics of generators is growing on me](https://macarthur.me/posts/generators/)
- ğŸ“œ [Reports of Deno's Demise Have Been Greatly Exaggerated](https://deno.com/blog/greatly-exaggerated)
- ğŸ“¦ [Node 22.16 \- `node.config.json` support (experimental)](https://nodejs.org/en/blog/release/v22.16.0)
- ğŸ“¦ [Zod 4.0 \- faster, slimmer, more tsc-efficient, new Zod Mini export, localization and more](https://zod.dev/v4)
- ğŸ“¦ [Remotion Media Parser \- Universal lib based on WebCodecs to parse/decode/encode videos](https://www.remotion.dev/blog/media-parser)
